title: What is schizophrenia? - Anees Bahji

multiple-choice.question: What is schizophrenia considered to be?

options.label: A
options.text: A single disorder with a known cause.

options.label: B
options.text: A syndrome that may encompass a number of related disorders.

options.label: C
options.text: A genetic disorder that is inherited from parents.

options.label: D
options.text: A mental illness that is caused by a virus.

multiple-choice.question: What are the first signs of schizophrenia often easy to miss?

options.label: B
options.text: Subtle personality changes, irritability, or a gradual encroachment of unusual thoughts.

multiple-choice.question: What typically occurs in the late teens or early twenties for men and the late twenties or early thirties for women?
What are called positive symptoms of schizophrenia?

options.label: A
options.text: Qualities that are reduced in people with schizophrenia.

options.label: B
options.text: Symptoms that occur in people with schizophrenia but not in the general population.

options.label: C
options.text: Symptoms that are caused by the use of antipsychotic drugs.

options.label: D
options.text: Symptoms that are caused by a virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is a common misperception about people with schizophrenia?

options.label: C
options.text: That they have a single personality.

multiple-choice.question: What are negative symptoms of schizophrenia?

options.label: A
options.text: Qualities that are increased in people with schizophrenia.

options.label: B
options.text: Qualities that are reduced in people with schizophrenia.

options.label: C
options.text: Symptoms that are caused by the use of antipsychotic drugs.

options.label: D
options.text: Symptoms that are caused by a virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is a strong genetic link associated with schizophrenia?

options.label: A
options.text: That children or siblings of people with schizophrenia are 10 times likelier to develop the disease.

options.label: B
options.text: That an identical twin of someone with schizophrenia has a 40% chance of being affected.

options.label: C
options.text: That schizophrenia is caused by a virus.

options.label: D
options.text: That schizophrenia is caused by a single gene.

multiple-choice.question: What may trigger the onset of psychosis in highly susceptible individuals?

options.label: A
options.text: Exposure to certain viruses in early infancy.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of some drugs, including marijuana.

multiple-choice.question: What are newer generations of antipsychotics aimed to address?

options.label: C
options.text: Multiple neurotransmitters, like serotonin in addition to dopamine.

options.label: D
options.text: Only the use of antipsychotic drugs.

multiple-choice.question: What can be very effective in reducing the likelihood of violence associated with schizophrenia?

options.label: B
options.text: Education for patients, their families, and their communities.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: That perception is not a biological process at all.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an illusion in which a person sees a rubber hand as their own hand, and it demonstrates that perception is an active process that involves the brain making predictions about the world.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It is an illusion in which a person sees a rubber hand as a separate object, and it demonstrates that perception is not a biological process at all.

options.label: C

options.label: B

title: How can we solve the antibiotic resistance crisis? - Gerry Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of antibiotics?

options.text: To prevent the growth of fungi.

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent the growth of bacteria.

options.label: C
options.text: Using phages, viruses that attack bacteria but don’t affect humans.

options.text: By using antibiotics in combination with other treatments.

options.label: B
options.text: By using antibiotics in combination with molecules that inhibit resistance.

multiple-choice.question: What is a major challenge to all approaches to combating bacterial resistance?

options.label: B
options.text: Using antibiotics in combination with molecules that inhibit resistance.

options.label: C
options.text: Using phages, viruses that attack bacteria but don’t affect humans.

options.label: D
options.text: Shifting profits away from the volume of antibiotics sold.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the Queen of the Night's voice can be heard so clearly above the strains of dozens of instruments in the opera house?

options.label: B
options.text: The physics of the human voice and the carefully honed technique of an expert opera singer.

options.label: C
options.text: The shape and material of the instruments used in the orchestra.

options.label: D
options.text: The size of the concert hall.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the lowest vibration of a note, which is what our ears mostly use to identify a note?
What is the term for the additional frequencies that layer on top of the fundamental vibration of a note?
What is the term for the specific frequencies that comprise the harmonic series of a note?
What is the term for the distinctive ringing timbre that an opera singer produces when they emphasize the partials in a certain range of frequencies?
What is the term for the musical effect in which a note slightly oscillates in pitch?
What is the term for the physical preparation that a singer needs to build up stamina to power through a long and demanding piece of music?
What is the term for the rigid surfaces in a concert hall that reflect sound waves towards the audience?
What is the term for the fact that different vocal signatures demand different physical preparation?
What is the term for the fact that biology sets some limits on what techniques a singer can use, and that voices change as singers age?

title: Why germs thrive on planes— and how to stop them - Raymond Wang

multiple-choice.question: How many people travel by plane every year?
What is the worst part about spreading diseases on airplanes?

options.label: A
options.text: It's difficult to pre-screen for diseases

options.label: B
options.text: It's easy to spread diseases on airplanes

options.label: C
options.text: It's expensive to install safety measures to prevent disease spread

options.label: D
options.text: It's not a problem at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the device that can reduce pathogen transmission by about 55 times and increase fresh-air inhalation by about 190 percent?
What is the main function of the Global Inlet Director?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase air pressure in the cabin

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce air pressure in the cabin

options.label: C
options.text: To create personalized breathing zones for passengers

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate all pathogens in the cabin

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated cost of the SARS epidemic?
What is the estimated cost of a big disease outbreak in the future?
How long does it take to install the Global Inlet Director?
What is the main advantage of the Global Inlet Director?

options.label: C
options.text: It can reduce pathogen transmission by 55 times

multiple-choice.question: What is the current era for innovation?
What is the question asked by the speaker at the end of the presentation?
